articles.title: New cosmic lens measurements deepen the Hubble tension mystery
articles.summary: Scientists are testing a novel way to measure cosmic expansion using time delays in gravitationally lensed quasars. Their results match “local” measurements but clash with early-universe estimates, strengthening the mysterious Hubble tension. This mismatch could point to new physics rather than observational error. Researchers now aim to boost precision to solve the puzzle.
articles.content:
Cosmologists are grappling with a major unresolved puzzle: they do not all agree on how fast the universe is expanding, and solving this puzzle could point to new physics. To check for hidden errors in traditional measurements that rely on markers such as supernovae, astronomers continually look for fresh ways to track cosmic expansion. In recent work, researchers including scientists at the University of Tokyo measured the universe's growth using new techniques and data from some of the most advanced telescopes available. Their approach takes advantage of the fact that light from extremely distant objects can travel to us along several different paths. Comparing these different routes helps refine models of what is happening on the very largest scales in the universe, including how space itself is stretching.

How fast is the universe expanding?

We know that the universe is enormous, and it is steadily growing larger. Its exact size is unknown, but its rate of expansion can be measured. This turns out to be more complicated than it sounds, because the expansion appears faster when we look at more distant regions of space. For every 3.3 million light years (or one megaparsec) of distance from Earth, objects at that distance appear to be moving away from us at about 73 kilometers per second. Put another way, the universe expands at 73 kilometers per second per megaparsec (km/s/Mpc), a value known as the Hubble constant.

Distance ladders and a new way to measure the Hubble constant

Scientists have developed several methods to estimate the Hubble constant, but until now they have all relied on so-called distance ladders. These ladders are built from objects such as supernovae and special stars called Cepheid variable stars. Because these objects are considered well understood, astronomers assume that even when they are observed in other galaxies, they can be used to estimate distances with high precision. Over decades of observations of many such objects, the allowed range for the Hubble constant has become narrower. However, some uncertainty has always remained about how reliable this approach is, so cosmologists are eager to test alternatives.

In their latest study, a team of astronomers that includes Project Assistant Professor Kenneth Wong and postdoctoral researcher Eric Paic from the University of Tokyo's Research Center for the Early Universe has successfully demonstrated a technique called time-delay cosmography. They argue that this method can reduce the field's dependence on distance ladders and could also have valuable applications in other branches of cosmology.

Using gravitational lensing as a cosmic measurement tool

"To measure the Hubble constant using time-delay cosmography, you need a really massive galaxy that can act as a lens," said Wong. "The gravity of this 'lens' deflects light from objects hiding behind it around itself, so we see a distorted version of them. This is called gravitational lensing. If the circumstances are right, we'll actually see multiple distorted images, and each will have taken a slightly different pathway to get to us, taking different amounts of time. By looking for identical changes in these images that are slightly out of step, we can measure the difference in time they took to reach us. Coupling this data with estimates on the distribution of the mass of the galactic lens that's distorting them is what allows us to calculate the acceleration of distant objects more accurately. The Hubble constant we measure is well within the ranges supported by other modes of estimation."

The Hubble tension: conflicting views of the expanding universe

It may seem puzzling that researchers invest so much effort to refine a number that has already been measured many times. The reason is that this value sits at the heart of how scientists reconstruct the history and evolution of the universe, and there is a serious unresolved discrepancy. The value of 73 km/s/Mpc for the Hubble constant agrees with observations of relatively nearby objects. However, there are other ways to infer the cosmic expansion rate that look much farther back in time. One key method uses the radiation that fills the universe and traces back to the big bang, known as the cosmic microwave background (CMB). When scientists analyze the CMB to estimate the Hubble constant, they obtain a lower value of 67 km/s/Mpc.

This mismatch between 73 km/s/Mpc and 67 km/s/Mpc is called the Hubble tension. The work by Wong, Paic and their colleagues helps illuminate what might be causing this tension, at a time when it is still unclear whether the discrepancy is simply due to experimental uncertainties or points to something deeper.

Is the Hubble tension pointing to new physics?

"Our measurement of the Hubble constant is more consistent with other current-day observations and less consistent with early-universe measurements. This is evidence that the Hubble tension may indeed arise from real physics and not just some unknown source of error in the various methods," said Wong. "Our measurement is completely independent of other methods, both early- and late-universe, so if there are any systematic uncertainties in those methods, we should not be affected by them."

"The main focus of this work was to improve our methodology, and now we need to increase the sample size to improve the precision and decisively settle the Hubble tension," said Paic. "Right now, our precision is about 4.5%, and in order to really nail down the Hubble constant to a level that would definitively confirm the Hubble tension, we need to get to a precision of around 1-2%."

More lenses, more quasars, and higher precision

The researchers are optimistic that they can reach this higher level of accuracy. In the current study, they analyzed eight time-delay lens systems. Each system contains a foreground galaxy that acts as a lens and blocks our direct view of a distant quasar (a supermassive black hole that is accreting gas and dust, causing it to shine brightly). They also incorporated new observations from cutting-edge space-based and ground-based observatories, including the James Webb Space Telescope. Looking ahead, the team plans to expand the number of lens systems they study, refine their measurements, and carefully identify or eliminate any remaining systematic sources of error.

Mass distribution uncertainties and a global cosmology effort

"One of the largest sources of uncertainty is the fact that we don't know exactly how the mass in the lens galaxies is distributed. It is usually assumed that the mass follows some simple profile that is consistent with observations, but it is hard to be sure, and this uncertainty can directly influence the values we calculate," said Wong. "The Hubble tension matters, as it may point to a new era in cosmology revealing new physics. Our project is the result of a decades-long collaboration between multiple independent observatories and researchers, highlighting the importance of international collaboration in science."

articles.personality_title: New cosmic lens method confirms mystery in universe’s expansion rate
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists want to know how fast the universe is expanding, measured by a number called the Hubble constant. Different methods give different answers, causing a puzzle known as the Hubble tension.

**What happened** – A team from the University of Tokyo used a new method called time-delay cosmography. They looked at distant quasars whose light bends around massive galaxies, creating multiple images that reach Earth at different times. Measuring these time delays helps calculate the universe’s expansion rate without relying on older methods based on stars and supernovae.

**Impact** – Their measurement supports the higher expansion rate seen in nearby objects but disagrees with lower rates from early universe data, like the cosmic microwave background. This strengthens the idea that the difference is not just an error but might reveal new physics about the universe.

**What's next step** – The researchers plan to study more lens systems and improve their measurements to reduce uncertainty from about 4.5% to 1-2%. This will help confirm whether the Hubble tension is real and what it means for cosmology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using a fresh cosmic lensing technique, scientists have reinforced the puzzling difference in the universe’s expansion speed, moving closer to solving a major cosmic mystery.

articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo método de lentes cósmicos confirma el misterio en la tasa de expansión del universo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos quieren saber qué tan rápido se está expandiendo el universo, medido por un número llamado constante de Hubble. Diferentes métodos dan respuestas distintas, creando un problema conocido como la tensión de Hubble.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de la Universidad de Tokio usó un nuevo método llamado cosmografía por retraso temporal. Observaron cuásares distantes cuya luz se desvía alrededor de galaxias masivas, creando varias imágenes que llegan a la Tierra en diferentes momentos. Medir estos retrasos ayuda a calcular la tasa de expansión del universo sin depender de métodos antiguos basados en estrellas y supernovas.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean estudiar más sistemas de lentes y mejorar sus mediciones para reducir la incertidumbre de alrededor del 4.5% a 1-2%. Esto ayudará a confirmar si la tensión de Hubble es real y qué significa para la cosmología.

articles.title: NASA Begins Moon Mission Plume-Surface Interaction Tests
articles.summary: In March, NASA researchers employed a new camera system to capture data imagery of the interaction between Firefly Aerospace Blue Ghost Mission-1 lander’s engine plumes and the lunar surface. Through NASA’s Artemis campaign, this data will help researchers understand the hazards that may occur when a lander’s engine plumes blast away at the lunar dust, […]
articles.content:
In March, NASA researchers employed a new camera system to capture data imagery of the interaction between Firefly Aerospace Blue Ghost Mission-1 lander’s engine plumes and the lunar surface.

Through NASA’s Artemis campaign, this data will help researchers understand the hazards that may occur when a lander’s engine plumes blast away at the lunar dust, soil, and rocks.

The data also will be used by NASA’s commercial partners as they develop their human landing systems to safely transport astronauts from lunar orbit to the Moon’s surface and back, beginning with Artemis III.

To better understand the science of lunar landings, a team at NASA’s Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia, has initiated a series of plume-surface interaction tests inside a massive 60-foot spherical vacuum chamber.

This plume-surface interaction ground test is the most complex test of its kind to be undertaken in a vacuum chamber Ashley Korzun PSI Testing Lead at NASA Langley

“This plume-surface interaction ground test is the most complex test of its kind to be undertaken in a vacuum chamber,” said Ashley Korzun, testing lead at NASA Langley. “If I’m in a spacecraft and I’m going to move all that regolith while landing, some of that’s going to hit my lander. Some of it’s going to go out toward other things — payloads, science experiments, eventually rovers and other assets. Understanding those physics is pivotal to ensuring crew safety and mission success.”

The campaign, which will run through spring of 2026, should provide an absolute treasure trove of data that researchers will be able to use to improve predictive models and influence the design of space hardware. As Korzun mentioned, it’s a big undertaking, and it involves multiple NASA centers, academic institutions, and commercial entities both small and large.

Korzun’ s team will test two types of propulsion systems in the vacuum sphere. For the first round of tests this fall, they are using an ethane plume simulation system designed by NASA’s Stennis Space Center near Bay St. Louis, Mississippi, and built and operated by Purdue University in West Lafayette, Indiana. The ethane system generates a maximum of about 100 pounds of thrust — imagine the force necessary to lift or support a 100-pound person. It heats up but doesn’t burn.

A view of the ethane nozzle researchers are using during the first phase of testing.

NASA/Wesley Chambers

After completing the ethane tests, the second round of tests will involve a 14-inch, 3D-printed hybrid rocket motor developed at Utah State University in Logan, Utah, and recently tested at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. It produces around 35 pounds of thrust, igniting both solid propellant and a stream of gaseous oxygen to create a hot, powerful stream of rocket exhaust, simulating a real rocket engine but at smaller scale for this test series.

Researchers will test both propulsion systems at various heights, firing them into a roughly six-and-a-half-foot diameter, one-foot-deep bin of simulated lunar regolith, called Black Point-1 that has jagged, cohesive properties similar to lunar regolith.

“It gives us a huge range of test conditions,” Korzun said, “to be able to talk about spacecraft of all different kinds going to the Moon, and for us to understand what they’re going to do as they land or try to take back off from the surface.”

Researchers will use this 14-inch, 3D-printed hybrid rocket motor during the second phase of testing.

The data from these tests at NASA Langley will be critical in developing and validating models to predict the effects of plume surface interaction for landing on the Moon and even Mars, ensuring mission success for the HLS landers and the safety of our astronauts Daniel Stubbs Engineer with HLS Plume and Aero Environments Team at NASA Marshall

A number of different instruments, including a version of the specialized camera system that imaged the plume-surface interaction during the Blue Ghost landing, will capture data and imagery from the tests, which will only last about six seconds each. The instruments will measure crater formation, the speed and angle of ejecta particles, and the shapes of the engine plumes.

Korzun sees this test campaign as more than a one-shot, Moon-specific thing. The entire operation is modular by design and can also prepare NASA for missions to Mars. The lunar regolith simulant can be replaced with a Mars simulant that’s more like sand. Pieces of hardware and instrumentation can be unbolted and replaced to represent future Mars landers. Rather than take the vacuum sphere down to really low pressure like on the Moon, it can be adjusted to a pressure that simulates the atmosphere on the Red Planet. “Mars has always been in our road maps,” Korzun said.

But for now, the Moon looms large.

A number of instruments, including SCALPSS cameras similar to the ones that captured imagery of the plume-surface interaction between Firefly Aerospace’s Blue Ghost lander and the Moon in March, will capture data on the sphere tests. NASA/Ryan Hill

“This test campaign is one of the most flight-relevant and highly instrumented plume-surface interaction test series NASA has ever conducted,” said Daniel Stubbs, an engineer with the human landing systems plume and aero environments team at NASA Marshall. “The data from these tests at NASA Langley will be critical in developing and validating models to predict the effects of plume-surface interaction for landing on the Moon and even Mars, ensuring mission success for the human landing systems and the safety of our astronauts.”

Through the Artemis campaign, NASA will send astronauts to explore the Moon for scientific discovery, economic benefits, and to build upon our foundation for the first crewed missions to Mars – for the benefit of all.

For more information about Artemis, visit:

https://www.nasa.gov/artemis

The testing platform is engineered to accommodate the engine nozzles, simulated lunar soil and instrumentation.

NASA/Wesley Chambers

Joe Atkinson

NASA Langley Research Center

articles.personality_title: NASA tests rocket plumes on moon dust to prepare for safe astronaut landings
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA is working on sending astronauts back to the Moon through its Artemis program. A big challenge is understanding how rocket engines affect the Moon’s surface when a spacecraft lands, because the engine blasts can kick up dust and rocks.

**What happened** – In March, NASA began using a special camera system to study the interaction between the Firefly Aerospace Blue Ghost lander’s rocket plumes and the lunar surface. Now, at NASA’s Langley Research Center, researchers have started a series of detailed tests inside a large vacuum chamber. They are firing simulated rocket plumes into a bin filled with fake moon soil to see how dust and rocks move. Two types of engines are being tested: one that uses heated ethane gas and another hybrid rocket motor built with 3D printing.

**Impact** – These tests are important because they help NASA understand how dust and debris behave during landings. This knowledge will help design safer spacecraft that protect astronauts and equipment. The data will also improve computer models used to predict landing conditions, which is crucial for Artemis missions and future trips to Mars. The vacuum chamber setup can even be adjusted to simulate Mars conditions, making the research valuable beyond the Moon.

**What's next step** – The testing will continue through spring 2026, covering many different landing scenarios. NASA will use the gathered data to refine spacecraft designs and safety measures. The results will support the development of human landing systems that will carry astronauts from lunar orbit to the surface and back starting with Artemis III.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s new ground tests of rocket plumes on simulated moon soil are helping ensure safe and successful landings for future astronaut missions to the Moon and Mars.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA teste les jets de fusée sur la poussière lunaire pour préparer des atterrissages sûrs
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA prépare le retour des astronautes sur la Lune grâce à son programme Artemis. Un grand défi est de comprendre comment les moteurs-fusées affectent la surface lunaire lors de l’atterrissage, car les jets peuvent soulever poussière et roches.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En mars, la NASA a commencé à utiliser un système de caméra spécial pour étudier l’interaction entre les jets du module Blue Ghost de Firefly Aerospace et la surface lunaire. Maintenant, au Centre de recherche Langley de la NASA, les chercheurs ont lancé une série de tests détaillés dans une grande chambre à vide. Ils tirent des jets de fusée simulés dans un bac rempli de sol lunaire artificiel pour observer le mouvement de la poussière et des roches. Deux types de moteurs sont testés : un utilisant de l’éthane chauffé et un autre moteur hybride imprimé en 3D.

**Impact** – Ces tests sont importants car ils aident la NASA à comprendre le comportement de la poussière et des débris lors des atterrissages. Ces connaissances permettront de concevoir des engins plus sûrs pour protéger astronautes et équipements. Les données amélioreront aussi les modèles informatiques de prédiction des conditions d’atterrissage, essentiels pour Artemis et les futures missions martiennes. La chambre à vide peut même être ajustée pour simuler l’atmosphère de Mars, rendant la recherche utile au-delà de la Lune.

**Prochaine étape** – Les tests continueront jusqu’au printemps 2026, couvrant plusieurs scénarios d’atterrissage. La NASA utilisera les données pour affiner les designs des engins spatiaux et les mesures de sécurité. Ces résultats soutiendront le développement des systèmes d’atterrissage humain qui transporteront les astronautes de l’orbite lunaire à la surface et retour, à partir d’Artemis III.

**Message-clé** – Les nouveaux tests au sol de la NASA sur les jets de fusée et le sol lunaire simulé aident à garantir des atterrissages sûrs et réussis pour les futures missions habitées vers la Lune et Mars.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA prueba chorros de cohete en polvo lunar para preparar aterrizajes seguros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA está preparando el regreso de astronautas a la Luna con su programa Artemis. Un gran reto es entender cómo los motores de cohetes afectan la superficie lunar al aterrizar, porque los chorros pueden levantar polvo y rocas.

**Qué pasó** – En marzo, la NASA comenzó a usar un sistema especial de cámaras para estudiar la interacción entre los chorros del módulo Blue Ghost de Firefly Aerospace y la superficie lunar. Ahora, en el Centro de Investigación Langley de la NASA, los investigadores iniciaron una serie de pruebas detalladas dentro de una gran cámara de vacío. Disparan chorros de cohete simulados en un contenedor con suelo lunar falso para observar cómo se mueve el polvo y las rocas. Se están probando dos tipos de motores: uno que usa gas etano calentado y otro motor híbrido impreso en 3D.

**Impacto** – Estas pruebas son importantes porque ayudan a la NASA a entender cómo se comportan el polvo y los escombros durante los aterrizajes. Esta información ayudará a diseñar naves más seguras para proteger a los astronautas y equipos. Los datos también mejorarán los modelos computacionales para predecir las condiciones de aterrizaje, algo crucial para Artemis y futuras misiones a Marte. La cámara de vacío puede ajustarse para simular la atmósfera de Marte, haciendo que la investigación sea útil más allá de la Luna.

**Próximo paso** – Las pruebas continuarán hasta la primavera de 2026, cubriendo varios escenarios de aterrizaje. La NASA usará los datos para mejorar el diseño de las naves y las medidas de seguridad. Los resultados apoyarán el desarrollo de sistemas de aterrizaje humano que llevarán astronautas desde la órbita lunar a la superficie y de regreso, empezando con Artemis III.

**Frase clave** – Las nuevas pruebas de la NASA con chorros de cohete y suelo lunar simulado ayudan a asegurar aterrizajes seguros y exitosos para futuras misiones humanas a la Luna y Marte.

articles.title: NASA Astronaut Jonny Kim, Crewmates Return from Space Station
articles.summary: NASA astronaut Jonny Kim returned to Earth on Tuesday alongside Roscosmos cosmonauts Sergey Ryzhikov and Alexey Zubritsky, wrapping up an eight-month science mission aboard the International Space Station to benefit life on Earth and future space exploration. They made a safe, parachute-assisted landing at 12:03 a.m. EST (10:03 a.m. local time), southeast of Dzhezkazgan, Kazakhstan, […]
articles.content:
The Soyuz MS-27 spacecraft is seen as it lands in a remote area near the town of Zhezkazgan, Kazakhstan, with Expedition 73 NASA astronaut Jonny Kim, and Roscosmos cosmonauts Sergey Ryzhikov, and Alexey Zubritsky aboard, Dec. 9, 2025. NASA/Bill Ingalls

NASA astronaut Jonny Kim returned to Earth on Tuesday alongside Roscosmos cosmonauts Sergey Ryzhikov and Alexey Zubritsky, wrapping up an eight-month science mission aboard the International Space Station to benefit life on Earth and future space exploration.

They made a safe, parachute-assisted landing at 12:03 a.m. EST (10:03 a.m. local time), southeast of Dzhezkazgan, Kazakhstan, after departing the space station at 8:41 p.m. on Dec. 8, aboard the Soyuz MS-27 spacecraft.

Over the course of 245 days in space, the crew orbited Earth 3,920 times, traveling nearly 104 million miles. They launched to the space station on April 8. This mission marked the first spaceflight for both Kim and Zubritsky, while Ryzhikov completed his third journey to space, logging a total of 603 days in space.

NASA astronaut Jonny Kim shows off the Matroyshka (stacking) doll he received upon his return to Earth, Dec. 9, 2025. Kim and his crewmates landed safely aboard their Soyuz MS-27 spacecraft in a remote area near the town of Zhezkazgan, Kazakhstan. NASA

While aboard the orbiting laboratory, Kim contributed to a wide range of scientific investigations and technology demonstrations. He studied the behavior of bioprinted tissues containing blood vessels in microgravity for an experiment helping advance space-based tissue production to treat patients on Earth. He also evaluated the remote command of multiple robots in space for the Surface Avatar study, which could support the development of robotic assistants for future exploration missions. Additionally, Kim worked on developing in-space manufacturing of DNA-mimicking nanomaterials, which could improve drug delivery technologies and support emerging therapeutics and regenerative medicine.

Following post-landing medical checks, the crew will return to the recovery staging area in Karaganda, Kazakhstan. Kim will then board a NASA aircraft bound for the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston.

For more than 25 years, people have lived and worked continuously aboard the International Space Station, advancing scientific knowledge and making research breakthroughs that are not possible on Earth. The station is a critical testbed for NASA to understand and overcome the challenges of long-duration spaceflight and to expand commercial opportunities in low Earth orbit. As commercial companies concentrate on providing human space transportation services and destinations as part of a robust low Earth orbit economy, NASA is focusing its resources on deep space missions to the Moon as part of the Artemis campaign in preparation for future human missions to Mars.

Learn more about International Space Station research and operations at:

https://www.nasa.gov/station

-end-

Josh Finch

Headquarters, Washington

202-358-1100

joshua.a.finch@nasa.gov

Sandra Jones / Joseph Zakrzewski

Johnson Space Center, Houston

281-483-5111

sandra.p.jones@nasa.gov / joseph.a.zakrzewski@nasa.gov

articles.personality_title: NASA astronaut Jonny Kim returns safely after eight months on space station
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA astronaut Jonny Kim and two Russian cosmonauts spent eight months aboard the International Space Station (ISS), conducting scientific research to help improve life on Earth and prepare for future space missions.

**What happened** – On December 9, 2025, Jonny Kim, along with cosmonauts Sergey Ryzhikov and Alexey Zubritsky, landed safely in Kazakhstan after leaving the ISS the previous evening. They traveled nearly 104 million miles and orbited Earth 3,920 times during their 245-day mission. This was Kim and Zubritsky’s first spaceflight, while Ryzhikov completed his third.

**Impact** – During the mission, Kim worked on important experiments like growing bioprinted tissues with blood vessels in space, which could help create better treatments for patients on Earth. He also tested controlling multiple robots remotely, which could support future space exploration. Additionally, Kim helped develop new materials that mimic DNA, potentially improving medicine delivery and regenerative treatments. These studies show how space research can lead to advances in health and technology.

**What’s next step** – After medical checkups in Kazakhstan, Kim will return to NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. Meanwhile, NASA continues to use the ISS to prepare for deep space missions, including trips to the Moon and Mars, while commercial companies work on new space travel options closer to Earth.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Jonny Kim and his crewmates completed a successful eight-month mission on the ISS, advancing science that could improve healthcare and support future space exploration.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'astronaute de la NASA Jonny Kim revient sain et sauf après huit mois à la station spatiale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'astronaute de la NASA Jonny Kim et deux cosmonautes russes ont passé huit mois à bord de la Station spatiale internationale (ISS), menant des recherches scientifiques pour améliorer la vie sur Terre et préparer les futures missions spatiales.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 9 décembre 2025, Jonny Kim, avec les cosmonautes Sergey Ryzhikov et Alexey Zubritsky, a atterri en toute sécurité au Kazakhstan après avoir quitté l'ISS la veille. Ils ont parcouru près de 104 millions de miles et fait 3 920 orbites autour de la Terre pendant leur mission de 245 jours. C'était le premier vol spatial pour Kim et Zubritsky, tandis que Ryzhikov effectuait son troisième.

**Impact** – Au cours de la mission, Kim a travaillé sur des expériences importantes, comme la croissance de tissus bio-imprimés avec des vaisseaux sanguins en microgravité, ce qui pourrait aider à créer de meilleurs traitements pour les patients sur Terre. Il a aussi testé le contrôle à distance de plusieurs robots, ce qui pourrait soutenir l'exploration spatiale future. De plus, Kim a aidé à développer de nouveaux matériaux imitant l'ADN, pouvant améliorer la livraison de médicaments et les traitements régénératifs. Ces études montrent comment la recherche spatiale peut faire avancer la santé et la technologie.

**Prochaine étape** – Après des examens médicaux au Kazakhstan, Kim retournera au centre spatial Johnson de la NASA à Houston. Pendant ce temps, la NASA continue d'utiliser l'ISS pour préparer les missions lointaines, notamment vers la Lune et Mars, tandis que des entreprises commerciales développent de nouvelles options de voyages spatiaux proches de la Terre.

**En une phrase** – Jonny Kim et ses coéquipiers ont mené à bien une mission de huit mois à l'ISS, faisant progresser la science pour améliorer la santé et soutenir l'exploration spatiale future.
articles.personality_title_es: El astronauta de la NASA Jonny Kim regresa sano y salvo tras ocho meses en la estación espacial
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El astronauta de la NASA Jonny Kim y dos cosmonautas rusos pasaron ocho meses en la Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI), realizando investigaciones científicas para mejorar la vida en la Tierra y preparar futuras misiones espaciales.

**Qué pasó** – El 9 de diciembre de 2025, Jonny Kim, junto con los cosmonautas Sergey Ryzhikov y Alexey Zubritsky, aterrizaron de forma segura en Kazajistán después de salir de la EEI la noche anterior. Recorrieorn casi 104 millones de millas y orbitadon la Tierra 3,920 veces durante su misión de 245 días. Fue el primer vuelo espacial para Kim y Zubritsky, mientras que Ryzhikov completó su tercero.

**Impacto** – Durante la misión, Kim trabajó en experimentos importantes como el crecimiento de tejidos bioimpresos con vasos sanguíneos en gravedad cero, lo que podría ayudar a crear mejores tratamientos para pacientes en la Tierra. También probó el control remoto de varios robots, lo que podría apoyar futuras exploraciones espaciales. Además, ayudó a desarrollar nuevos materiales que imitan el ADN, que podrían mejorar la entrega de medicamentos y tratamientos regenerativos. Estos estudios muestran cómo la investigación espacial puede avanzar en salud y tecnología.

**Próximo paso** – Tras chequeos médicos en Kazajistán, Kim regresará al Centro Espacial Johnson de la NASA en Houston. Mientras tanto, la NASA sigue usando la EEI para preparar misiones de larga duración, como viajes a la Luna y Marte, mientras empresas comerciales trabajan en nuevas opciones de transporte espacial cerca de la Tierra.

**Frase clave** – Jonny Kim y sus compañeros completaron una exitosa misión de ocho meses en la EEI, avanzando en la ciencia para mejorar la salud y apoyar la exploración espacial futura.

articles.title: Astronomers capture sudden black hole blast firing ultra fast winds
articles.summary: A sudden X-ray flare from a supermassive black hole in galaxy NGC 3783 triggered ultra-fast winds racing outward at a fifth the speed of light—an event never witnessed before. Using XMM-Newton and XRISM, astronomers caught the blast unfold in real time, revealing how tangled magnetic fields can rapidly “untwist” and hurl matter into space much like an enormous, cosmic-scale version of the Sun’s coronal mass ejections.
articles.content:
Leading X-ray observatories XMM-Newton and XRISM have captured a remarkable and previously unrecorded eruption from a supermassive black hole. Over the course of only a few hours, the intense gravity of this object stirred up extremely fast winds that pushed material outward at an astonishing 60,000 km per second.

This enormous black hole sits in NGC 3783, a striking spiral galaxy recently photographed by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. Astronomers observed a bright X-ray flare burst from the black hole and fade almost immediately. As the flare diminished, high-velocity winds appeared, racing outward at roughly one-fifth the speed of light.

"We've not watched a black hole create winds this speedily before," says lead researcher Liyi Gu at Space Research Organization Netherlands (SRON). "For the first time, we've seen how a rapid burst of X-ray light from a black hole immediately triggers ultra-fast winds, with these winds forming in just a single day."

Inside an Active Galactic Nucleus

To investigate NGC 3783 and its central black hole, Gu and his team used the European Space Agency's XMM-Newton together with the X-Ray Imaging and Spectroscopy Mission (XRISM), a JAXA-led mission with ESA and NASA participation.

The black hole, containing the mass of about 30 million Suns, consumes nearby gas and dust. This activity powers a brilliantly luminous and energetic zone at the galaxy's center called an Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN). AGNs emit light across the electromagnetic spectrum and can drive strong jets and winds into their surroundings.

"AGNs are really fascinating and intense regions, and key targets for both XMM-Newton and XRISM," notes Matteo Guainazzi, ESA XRISM Project Scientist and co-author of the discovery.

"The winds around this black hole seem to have been created as the AGN's tangled magnetic field suddenly 'untwisted' -- similar to the flares that erupt from the Sun, but on a scale almost too big to imagine."

Black Hole Winds That Echo Solar Eruptions

The newly detected winds resemble the Sun's coronal mass ejections, powerful outbursts that launch huge clouds of charged material into space. This comparison suggests that, in some moments, a supermassive black hole can behave in ways similar to our own star, making these distant giants feel slightly more familiar.

A real-world example occurred on November 11, when the Sun produced a coronal mass ejection following an intense flare. The material expelled during that solar event shot out at initial speeds of 1500 km per second.

"Windy AGNs also play a big role in how their host galaxies evolve over time, and how they form new stars," says Camille Diez, a team member and ESA Research Fellow.

"Because they're so influential, knowing more about the magnetism of AGNs, and how they whip up winds such as these, is key to understanding the history of galaxies throughout the Universe."

Two Telescopes Working in Unison

XMM-Newton has spent more than 25 years exploring the hottest and most extreme environments in space, while XRISM has been studying how matter and energy move through the Universe since its launch in September 2023.

Together, these missions uncovered this extraordinary episode and helped scientists understand the flare and the resulting winds. XMM-Newton followed the evolution of the flare with its Optical Monitor and measured the reach of the winds using the European Photon Imaging Camera (EPIC). XRISM detected the flare and winds with its Resolve instrument, which analyzed their velocity, structure, and the processes that launched them.

"Their discovery stems from successful collaboration, something that's a core part of all ESA missions," explains ESA XMM-Newton Project Scientist Erik Kuulkers.

"By zeroing in on an active supermassive black hole, the two telescopes have found something we've not seen before: rapid, ultra-fast, flare-triggered winds reminiscent of those that form at the Sun. Excitingly, this suggests that solar and high-energy physics may work in surprisingly familiar ways throughout the Universe."
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific breakthrough in astrophysics: astronomers have for the first time observed ultra-fast winds triggered by a sudden black hole flare in real time. This discovery enhances understanding of black hole behavior and galaxy evolution, with broad implications for space science and astrophysics. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights the collaboration of major space observatories, representing a meaningful advancement in knowledge about the universe.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers observe black hole flare launching ultra-fast winds for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Supermassive black holes sit at the centers of many galaxies and can pull in gas and dust. This activity creates very bright regions called Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), which can release energy and matter into space in winds and jets.

**What happened** – Astronomers using two space telescopes, XMM-Newton and XRISM, watched a sudden X-ray flare from a black hole in galaxy NGC 3783. This flare quickly triggered winds moving outward at about 60,000 kilometers per second, or one-fifth the speed of light. The event happened over just a few hours and was caught in real time.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have seen such fast winds form immediately after a black hole flare. The winds are thought to come from magnetic fields near the black hole suddenly untwisting, similar to solar flares on the Sun but on a much larger scale. Understanding these winds helps explain how black holes affect their galaxies, including how stars form and how galaxies grow.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue studying black holes and their magnetic fields using these telescopes to learn more about how such winds form and influence galaxies. This discovery may also help connect solar physics with phenomena around black holes in space.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, astronomers have seen a black hole flare trigger ultra-fast winds, revealing new details about how black holes interact with their galaxies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes observent pour la première fois une éruption de trou noir lançant des vents ultra-rapides
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les trous noirs supermassifs se trouvent au centre de nombreuses galaxies et attirent le gaz et la poussière autour d’eux. Cette activité crée des régions très lumineuses appelées noyaux actifs de galaxies (NAG), qui peuvent émettre de l’énergie et des vents dans l’espace.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des astronomes utilisant deux télescopes spatiaux, XMM-Newton et XRISM, ont observé une soudaine éruption de rayons X provenant d’un trou noir dans la galaxie NGC 3783. Cette éruption a rapidement déclenché des vents se déplaçant à environ 60 000 kilomètres par seconde, soit un cinquième de la vitesse de la lumière. L’événement s’est produit en quelques heures et a été capturé en temps réel.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que les scientifiques voient des vents aussi rapides se former immédiatement après une éruption de trou noir. Ces vents proviennent probablement de champs magnétiques près du trou noir qui se déroulent soudainement, un peu comme les éruptions solaires sur le Soleil, mais à une échelle beaucoup plus grande. Comprendre ces vents aide à expliquer comment les trous noirs influencent leurs galaxies, notamment la formation des étoiles et la croissance des galaxies.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier les trous noirs et leurs champs magnétiques avec ces télescopes pour mieux comprendre la formation de ces vents et leur influence sur les galaxies. Cette découverte pourrait aussi rapprocher la physique solaire des phénomènes autour des trous noirs dans l’espace.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, les astronomes ont vu une éruption de trou noir déclencher des vents ultra-rapides, révélant de nouveaux détails sur l’interaction des trous noirs avec leurs galaxies.
articles.personality_title_es: Astrónomos observan por primera vez una llamarada de agujero negro que lanza vientos ultra rápidos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los agujeros negros supermasivos están en el centro de muchas galaxias y atraen gas y polvo a su alrededor. Esta actividad crea regiones muy brillantes llamadas Núcleos Activos de Galaxias (AGN), que pueden emitir energía y vientos hacia el espacio.

Qué pasó** – Astrónomos usando dos telescopios espaciales, XMM-Newton y XRISM, observaron una repentina llamarada de rayos X de un agujero negro en la galaxia NGC 3783. Esta llamarada desencadenó rápidamente vientos que se movieron a unos 60,000 kilómetros por segundo, o una quinta parte de la velocidad de la luz. El evento ocurrió en pocas horas y fue capturado en tiempo real.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los científicos ven vientos tan rápidos formarse inmediatamente después de una llamarada de agujero negro. Se cree que estos vientos provienen de campos magnéticos cerca del agujero negro que se desenredan de repente, parecido a las erupciones solares en el Sol pero a una escala mucho mayor. Entender estos vientos ayuda a explicar cómo los agujeros negros afectan a sus galaxias, incluyendo la formación de estrellas y el crecimiento galáctico.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores continuarán estudiando los agujeros negros y sus campos magnéticos con estos telescopios para aprender más sobre cómo se forman estos vientos y cómo influyen en las galaxias. Este descubrimiento también podría ayudar a conectar la física solar con los fenómenos cerca de los agujeros negros en el espacio.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Por primera vez, los astrónomos han visto una llamarada de agujero negro que provoca vientos ultra rápidos, revelando nuevos detalles sobre cómo los agujeros negros interactúan con sus galaxias.
